chapter.htmlHeader: What are the risk factors?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• The risk factors for uncomplicated vulvovaginal candidiasis include: 
    • Oestrogen exposure — oestrogen is thought to play an essential role in the development of vulvovaginal candidiasis [Nwokolo and Boag, 2000; Fischer, 2012; FSRH, 2012]; therefore, the condition is more common during the reproductive years and during pregnancy.
      • The incidence rises rapidly after the menarche and peaks in the third and fourth decade of life. Pre-pubertal girls and postmenopausal women rarely have vulvovaginal candidiasis without an underlying predisposing factor [Sobel, 2003; Hayes and Creighton, 2007; Sobel, 2007; BNF 72, 2016; BNF for Children, 2017; Fischer and Bradford, 2016].
      • During pregnancy, asymptomatic vaginal colonization with Candida, acute vulvovaginal candidiasis, recurrent infection, and treatment failure are all more common [CDC, 2015; BNF 72, 2016].
    • Immunocompromised state — vulvovaginal candidiasis is common (and recurs frequently) in women who are immunocompromised, for example women with HIV infection [Ray et al, 2011]  [Nelson et al, 2011]. However, it is no more severe in this group than in women without HIV [Duerr et al, 2003].
    • Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus — the risk of symptomatic vulvovaginal candidiasis is increased in women with poorly managed diabetes. Women without diabetes who have recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis tend to have substantially higher blood glucose levels (but still within the normal range). The prevalence of vulvovaginal candidiasis is not increased in women with well-controlled diabetes [Sobel, 2007].
    • Treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics — vulvovaginal candidiasis occurs in about 30% of women taking a course of systemic or intravaginal antibiotics. However, only women who are already colonized with Candida are at risk of vulvovaginal candidiasis following treatment with antibiotics [Sobel, 2007].
    • Local irritants — expert opinion in guidelines is that local irritants (such as soaps, shower gels, and ‘feminine hygiene’ products) and tight-fitting, synthetic clothing can predispose to (or exacerbate) symptomatic vulvovaginal candidiasis [BASHH, 2007b; FSRH, 2012; RCGP, 2013], but the evidence for these is limited, conflicting, or absent. Evidence from observational studies suggests that vaginal douching increases the risk of infection and other adverse effects [Lopez, 2015].
    • Sexual behaviours — vulvovaginal candidiasis is not a sexually transmitted infection (STI); however, it can be triggered by sex, especially if there is vaginal dryness and tightness during intercourse. Women receiving oral sex may be at greater risk of vulvovaginal candidiasis, and it can rarely be passed on to sexual partners.
    • Contraception — contraceptive methods may play a part in the development (and also promote recurrences of vulvovaginal candidiasis):
      • Use of spermicidal jellies and creams increases susceptibility to infection by altering the vaginal flora and increasing the adhesion of Candida organisms [Ringdahl, 2000].
      • It is thought that women who take oral contraceptive pills, especially combined oral contraceptives (COCs), have a higher rate of vulvovaginal candidiasis, but the evidence for this is contradictory [Sobel, 2007; FSRH, 2012; Lopez, 2015]. One theory is that Candida cells have estrogen and progesterone receptors that, when stimulated, increase fungal proliferation [Ringdahl, 2000]. Limited evidence suggests that switching to a progestogen-only injectable contraceptive may help relieve symptoms in women with recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis; the effect of switching to other progestogen-only forms of contraception is uncertain [FSRH, 2012].
    • Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) — there is some evidence that postmenopausal women taking HRT are significantly more prone to develop vulvovaginal candidiasis than women who are not, and those who develop vulvovaginal candidiasis are likely to have been susceptible to it before menopause [Fischer and Bradford, 2011; Fischer and Bradford, 2016]. 
  • The predisposing factors for recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis are uncertain, as the aetiology is poorly understood [Cooke et al, 2011; CDC, 2015].
    • Possible causes of recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis include non-compliance with treatment, resistance of non–albicans Candida species (such as Candida glabrata) to conventional imidazole treatment (seen in 10–20% of women with recurrent cases), and continued exposure to risk factors. However, about 50% of women with recurrent cases have no apparent predisposing or underlying conditions [Ringdahl, 2000; CDC, 2015].
    • Several theories, such as maladaptive immune response, remain controversial, and the role of individual susceptibility has not yet been defined [Sobel, 2007; Cooke et al, 2011].
